newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Ngai Tahu Maori seek more talks on settlement.
newsitem.headline: Ngai Tahu Maori seek more talks on settlement.

text.p: South Island Maori tribe Ngai Tahu are pressing government ministers to free up more time for negotiations if they want a deal on the historical land claim before the election.

Prime Minister Jim Bolger told a meeting of the Hawkes' Bay Maori Business Association late on Wednesday that "Crown and Ngai Tahu negotiators are now well advanced in working through the details of the large Ngai Tahu claim and are making good progress".
"We may get an agreement in principle before the election," Bolger said.
But in an interview with Reuters on Thursday, Ngai Tahu chief negotiator Sir Tipene O'Regan seemed less optimistic, although he said an agreement in principle was still possible.
"There are a few -- very few -- major stumbling blocks in which the Ngai Tahu and Crown positions appear to be irreconcilable," O'Regan said.
"These issues have to be cleared at a political level. They are not really for officials to negotiate."
He said an agreement in principle would depend on the government "better activating its negotiating process".
"You'll appreciate the election season makes it extremely difficult to get the full attention of ministers."

Beehive sources said the government had put a "final offer" to the Ngai Tahu of about the same size as the successful $170 million Tanui Waikato settlement struck last year. But there were differences between the parties over whether customary or aboriginal rights would be included in the settlement.
One source said the smaller eastern North Island Whakatohea claim was also close to settlement.
New Zealand First's Te Tai Rawhiti electorate candidate John Delamere is chief negotiator for the Whakatohea claim.

The government is keen to settle land claims before the election, due on October 12, to reap the political benefit while Maori negotiators are keen to see a settlement now because a change of government could slow or interupt the process.
An announcement on at least part of the Ngai Tahu setlement is expected early next week.
